title: Will any member of China's Politburo resign, be suspended, or be removed from the Politburo in 2016?
preds: No reports so far, that sound anything like this one:
Affirming forecast for the passage of time.
china has a record of removing officials for corruption etc so it's possible, but unlikely

Epoch Times (analysis & opinion), December 1, 'China’s Xi Jinping Paves Political Transition With Anti-Corruption Drive': http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2191503-chinas-xi-jinping-paves-political-transition-with-anti-corruption-drive-2/
Clips from article:
"Beyond the Party?
Through the anti-corruption campaign, Xi Jinping has placed himself in a position that allows for all kinds of future political scenarios that would be impossible under Jiang Zemin, whose power stemmed from corruption and kleptocracy.  
Already, Chinese scholars have suggested the possibility of China’s taking on a presidential system of governance.
In November, the Xi leadership rolled out a pilot program for a new state anti-corruption body that answers to the Chinese legislature, and not the executive branch. Having this body answerable to the legislature may anticipate a change in the structure of the Chinese regime, with the Party no longer being in charge of everything.
If Xi takes the anti-corruption campaign to its logical conclusion, the inadvertent outcome might be a post-communist China."
Running out of time, and not much happening.
Adjust for the passing of time and consensus

Epoch Times, November 16, 'Exclusive: China’s Anti-Corruption Chief Will Be Exempt From Forced Retirement': http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2186725-exclusive-chinas-anti-corruption-chief-will-be-exempt-from-forced-retirement/
Clips from Epoch article:
"‘Rather the Devil Than Wang’
Xi and his supporters agreed that “Wang Qishan must remain in office,” despite the retirement age, because he’s their best candidate to head anti-corruption investigations and disciplinary reforms, according to the source.
Xi launched the anti-corruption campaign shortly after taking office, and vowed to crack down on both low and high-ranking officials who abuse their positions for personal gain. Xi also appears to be using the campaign, which is very popular with the Chinese people, to eliminate the faction of Jiang Zemin, the Party elder responsible for fostering pervasive corruption in China.
Wang was placed as head of the anti-corruption agency in 2012, and has overseen the arrest of more than a million officials—more than 150 of whom were high-ranking Party cadres in the government, state-run enterprises, and the military.
Officials are said to prefer meeting “the Devil” rather than Wang, a gaunt-looking man with a steely gaze. Under Wang’s watch, officials who were considered “untouchable,” like the former Politburo member Bo Xilai and the powerful security czar Zhou Yongkang, were probed and handed over for prosecution."
Adjusting for the shorter time horizon

Reuters, September 30, 'Exclusive: Xi set to consolidate power in China by curbing Communist Youth League': http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-politics-league-exclusive-idUSKCN1200OL
Clips from article:
"Among those on the Standing Committee, only Xi, 63, and Premier Li Keqiang, 61 – who is a member of the Youth League faction - will not have reached retirement age by the time of next year's congress. They are both widely expected to retain their No. 1 and 2 spots on the committee, the sources and diplomats said. The other five will most likely retire based on what has happened at previous congresses.
Lowering based on passage of time. I think it may happen but not until next year.

There is only one quarter left. Changes in the politburo are not that common bar corruption scandals. I'm not aware of any rumours of allegations against any of the members at this point. There is an official reshuffle planned in 2017 anyway, so there is less need for Xi to force a change in 2016

» Xi is trying to prevent the Communist Youth League faction from dominating the party’s seven-member Standing Committee during the 19th congress next year, .... If the three potential Youth League candidates – Vice President Li Yuanchao (no relation to Premier Li), Vice Premier Wang Yang and Guangdong provincial party boss Hu Chunhua (no relation to former president Hu) – were elected at the Congress, the Youth League faction would have a majority on the body and that would be unacceptable to Xi, the sources said. All three are currently members of the Politburo.
@dkc Hot phase started, session next month.
Adjusting for time. No mention in the following article about any major moves as yet.
Already September. If indictments were going to happen, they would have earlier in the year, since Politburo members will be standing down anyway in 2017.

China's anti-corruption campaign serves the purpose of getting rid of leaders that are both corrupt as well as opponents of Xi Jinping; he's already succeeded in removing the biggest obstacles to his goals, so there is little reason to remove any current Politburo members. Additionally, all major CPC meetings for the year have been held.

Down 10% to be more under the consensus. I expect it might happen, but can offer very plausible reasons that things will just "go along."

Why Xi Jinping’s bid to put ‘power in a cage’ must go to the very top
Coming up with clear rules to govern the members of China’s Politburo – and their families – presents the leadership with one of its biggest tests yet
http://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/2009570/why-xi-jinpings-bid-put-power-cage-must-go-very-top

There is some fast shuffling going on, as there often is at this point in the cycle.  The Big Kahuna seems committed to consolidating his authority in the fairly near future.  Anybody left on the Politburo who is not among his BFFs should keep luggage packed and passport up to date.

Some of these folks are term-limited next year anyway and may refer to their resignations as "retirement," apparently not contemplated by the wording of this Q.  One hopes that premature retirements will be counted as resignations, but one is never sure around here.

Newsweek (opinion), August 20, 'CHINA’S XI JINPING IS EYEING A RETURN TO SUPREME POWER': http://www.newsweek.com/chinas-xi-jinping-eyeing-return-supreme-power-dictator-491894
Clip from article:
"...... As the late political scientist Tang Tsou put it, the struggle for power in China is, above everything, a game of winner-take-all. Like Mao and Deng before him, Xi is playing not to compromise, but to win."

Rumors now abound within the party about whether he will be replaced as premier in next year’s reshuffling of key party posts. Messrs. Xi and Li are the only two members of the seven-man Politburo Standing Committee—the top leadership body—not due to retire.

WSJ (opinion), July 5, 'The Xi Jinping Ascendancy - A winner-takes-all political struggle continues in China.': http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-xi-jinping-ascendancy-1467748121
Clips from article:
'While the “tiger hunt” for top-level cadres may be over, that doesn’t mean Mr. Xi has consolidated power. China’s political struggle continues in other guises. This will make government policies unpredictable and risks conflict spilling out into public view in ways not seen since 1989.
The culmination of these maneuvers could be the removal of Premier Li Keqiang, the one Hu ally on the seven-member Politburo Standing Committee, the pinnacle of Chinese politics. Mr. Li would normally serve a 10-year term through 2022, but rumors are flying that Mr. Xi will force him to retire at the Party Congress next year and move other Hu allies into ceremonial positions.
Attacking rival factions’ right to exist violates a key tenet of Chinese elite politics since Deng Xiaoping’s rise to power in 1979. The top leader has always governed in consensus with other leaders who maintained their own power bases. These factions competed for key positions but did not seek to eliminate each other. This tradition was designed to prevent a repeat of Mao’s purges. Mr. Xi has upended this decision making by consensus and made himself the decider in all policy realms.'
Comments: Li Keqiang. Another name surfaces. Says, he may be eased out next year among others, but..... hey

Epoch Times, June 15, 'Chinese Regime Is China’s Propaganda Chief Headed for a Fall?': http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2093009-is-chinas-propaganda-chief-headed-for-a-fall/
Clips from article:
"Propaganda chief Liu Yunshan is a known loyalist of Jiang Zemin the former Party boss. Before Xi took power, Jiang allowed his loyalists in the Politburo Standing Committee—military vice chairs Xu Caihou and Guo Boxiong, and security czar Zhou Yongkang, to name a few—to have the final say on their respective portfolios. In turn, Jiang’s loyalists are committed to protecting their patron because it allows for the continuation of the political order that he oversees.
Xi seeks real control over the Party, and the only way to do that is by dislodging the Jiang power nexus. He has already purged many of Jiang’s top allies, and assumed control over the Party’s gun through a sweeping military reform. The other key Party organ, the Propaganda Department, seems to be next."
Overseas Chinese-language media have recently carried rumors that Liu Yunshan could be purged, and his Propaganda Department reconstituted."

April 2016 commentary on the Panama Papers and China : http://www.chinapost.com.tw/china/national-news/2016/04/08/462883/p1/China-Politburo.htm

Someone has to take blame for corruption and slowing economy.

On reading my rationale, going for 100% that there is an arrest of politburo for corruption, he has gone too far and since the politburo is not completely behind him in this investigation and reforms,  he will extend the investigation and it is not difficult to discover an official in a politburo position who is corrupt and in opposition of him and then removed for someone who supports Xi and his followers.

The corruption investigation, and the corruption in China was well known prior to the investigation, and generally ignored, includes  jail or execution and has several reasons for the rise in the investigations. Here are two of them. 
Xi wants to stabilize the economy by standardizing the amount of production of materials and commodities. There has been an over production of material that has led to over construction and  unsold cheaper goods that has pressured an all ready weakening economy. Over production has led to graft. 
Some data has been skewed and over valued. Employee tells manager that production was A and manager tells director that production was B and director tells regional director that production was C and so forth. All are given kickback with the least amount going to the employee  and the government publishes the skewed data for investors. This is why Xi has arrested people on all levels. But also, if a person was an associate of someone who was arrested, particularly a business associate to someone who was an arrested government official, the business associate was probably arrested, unless he or she gave evidence of others who may have been corrupt, and given another sentence or excused. 
But the arrests also gives more power to Xi by removing his enemies or opposition, As the economy slides, the Chinese leadership needs a pharmowitnessed kos, and more are being arrested and it will continue into the politburo once his or her supporters are arrested or too afraid to support the arrested official. We this with Mao and that was not long ago.  In some ways, he is forced to fight the corruption, but it works politically for him in image and ruling.

1) Top leadership controls: a) narrative b) military & security forces.
2) Tends to ignore what the West says about them.
3) A culture that values great wealth. Those who can do; off-shore accounts, foreign businesses, commercial and residential real-estate, etc. Everyone else works hard to acquire it. That's the norm.
4) Anti-corruption campaign hits the ceiling at 'middle-management'.
5) A general population subservient to the State. Tiananmen Square was an anomaly.
After the cleansing in the 17th Politburo (4 members, 2 jailed and 2 expelled), members know they will be watched closely and are taking measures not to get caught.
I'm certain at least one member will be dismissed in 2016
The Big Kahuna needs to show he's tough and serious about the anti-corruption choreography.  Too early to guess who the lucky winner(s) will be.  Stay alert to the odour of cooking goose.
Continuing fall-out from the Panama Papers, plus economic uncertainty will drive more scapegoating.

As the leadership becomes smaller to make more of a dictatorship, the leadership will remove people it thinks will challenge the politburo by arresting them for corruption or working against the leadership. The corruption trope has worked and as the economy drifts, the easier to charge people with corruption and the economy is drifting to where the leadership will increase their strategy to force more people out of leadership and the politburo.

China's growing nervousness about corruption  feeding a popular revolt will send the politburo in high gear to show the public.
It is surely the people's republic. Several high level member of the  party will be removed, resign suspended and prosecuted in the courts.

"http://www.wsj.com/articles/reports-of-offshore-companies-raise-questions-about-beijings-graft-fight-1459869258 in IFP and its blocked oh well here is a taste." Apart from Mr. Xi, who has a brother-in-law named in the Panama Papers, the documents also identified Vice Premier Zhang Gaoli and top party propagandist Liu Yunshan—both Politburo Standing Committee members—as having relatives who are shareholders of offshore companies, according to the British Broadcasting Corp., one of the more than 100 news organizations that have examined the Panama Papers"
Up 10% to be above the consensus.
Xi has been conducting an anti-corruption drive. He can hardly not purge obviously corrupt Party Members when large numbers of the population know the truth via QQ, Weibo and other such sites.

I assume this question refers to the 25 member Central politburo and not the 7 member standing committee. Even if it's the former there' s not a huge number of precedents to suggest that a resignation is likely. I think there's been three resignations in eleven years. The Panama papers have linked a few more members to the possibility of family links to corrupt conduct. Paradoxically though, the possibility of several members (including three members of the seven member standing committee) being involved may save them individually, as forced resignations seem in the past to have resulted from consensus decisions by other members.There remains the possibility of further Panama revelations but even so I see a resignation as unlikely.

At least eight current or former members of the all-powerful Politburo standing committee are among the more than 140 political figures worldwide linked to the offshore tax havens. 
Global investigation by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ)

There doesn't seem to any imminent expectation that any particular politburo member will resign.  Previous politburos have seen resignations, but not frequently.  I'd estimate a 25% chance, with a higher estimate after optimizing for early closure.
Up 10% to be more above consensus (which is increasing).
Based on what I've read from other forecasters, the fight against corruption, and the prospect of a power struggle, I think there's a fair chance of change in the Politburo before this year is out.
China needs to make an example out of someone to calm the public about corruption. I don't know who, but it's likely that someone goes down this year.

I don't know about the pots and pans in the Chinese Politburo, but from this one sentence I can smell something is cooking:

One highly unlikely,  Several?  Well that's a more interesting discussion.
As shaky as China's economy might appear to outside observers, it's hard to believe the economic and political environment deteriorating so much it would compel such an extreme action to be taken
The Politburo is highly impervious to scandal or outside pressure. Of course, chances of economic scapegoating, intercine conflict, fatal illness exist, and there is some economic instability ahead.

Scapegoats are brilliant for strengthening regimes! Add that to: 1. We have Xi pushing the anti-corruption stance; 2. There is a definitive connection in Panama Papers of few top guns; 3. Look at boz's data, precedents are available; 4. There is public pressure.
Xi will do what he needs to do to solidify his position, someone will go the question is will they go without  a gun to their head.

Four of the five past Politburos, going back to 1987, have had at least one person dismissed or resign. Each of the previous two Politburos had one person dismissed during the final two years (Bo Xilai in 2012; Chen Liangyu in 2006). Nobody has yet been dismissed or resigned from the current five year Politburo, in power since November 2012.
